properties.name: client
properties.description: The Apollo Client instance.

properties.name: document
properties.description: GraphQL Document

properties.name: context
properties.description: Context to be passed to link execution chain.

properties.name: data
properties.description: Latest data

properties.name: error
properties.description: Latest error

properties.name: errors
properties.description: Latest errors

properties.name: loading
properties.description: Whether a request is in flight.

properties.name: client
properties.description:
Reference to the `ApolloClient` instance.
Defaults to `window.__APOLLO_CLIENT` if not set.

tags.name: apollo-mutation
tags.description:
Simple Mutation component that takes a button or link-wrapped button as it's trigger.
When loading, it disables the button.
On error, it toasts a snackbar with the error message.
You can pass a `variables` object property,
or if all your variables properties are strings,
you can use the element's data attributes

attributes.name: input-key
attributes.description:
When set, variable data attributes will be packed into an
object property with the name of this property
##### Example
```html
<apollo-mutation id="a" data-variable="var"></apollo-mutation>
<apollo-mutation id="b" input-key="input" data-variable="var"></apollo-mutation>
<script>
   console.log(a.variables) // { variable: 'var' }
   console.log(b.variables) // { input: { variable: 'var' } }
</script>
```

attributes.name: refetch-queries
attributes.description: Specifies the FetchPolicy to be used for this mutation.

attributes.name: called
attributes.description: Whether the mutation has been fired

properties.name: inputKey
properties.description:
When set, variable data attributes will be packed into an
object property with the name of this property
##### Example
```html
<apollo-mutation id="a" data-variable="var"></apollo-mutation>
<apollo-mutation id="b" input-key="input" data-variable="var"></apollo-mutation>
<script>
   console.log(a.variables) // { variable: 'var' }
   console.log(b.variables) // { input: { variable: 'var' } }
</script>
```

properties.name: routeGetter
properties.description:
For Mutations that should trigger navigations,
a function of `data` to determine the href.

properties.name: mutation
properties.description: The mutation.

properties.name: optimisticResponse
properties.description:
An object that represents the result of this mutation that
will be optimistically stored before the server has actually returned a
result.

This is most often used for optimistic UI, where we want to be able to see
the result of a mutation immediately, and update the UI later if any errors
appear.

properties.name: errorPolicy
properties.description: Specifies the ErrorPolicy to be used for this mutation.

properties.name: fetchPolicy
properties.description: Specifies the FetchPolicy to be used for this mutation.

properties.name: refetchQueries
properties.description: Specifies the FetchPolicy to be used for this mutation.

properties.name: awaitRefetchQueries
properties.description:
Queries refetched as part of refetchQueries are handled asynchronously,
and are not waited on before the mutation is completed (resolved).
Setting this to true will make sure refetched queries are completed
before the mutation is considered done. false by default.

properties.name: called
properties.description: Whether the mutation has been fired

properties.name: ignoreResults
properties.description: If true, the returned data property will not update with the mutation result.

properties.name: mostRecentMutationId
properties.description: The ID number of the most recent mutation since the element was instantiated.

properties.name: variables
properties.description: An object that maps from the name of a variable as used in the mutation GraphQL document to that variable's value.

properties.name: client
properties.description: The Apollo Client instance.

properties.name: document
properties.description:
GraphQL operation document i.e. query, subscription, or mutation.
Must be a parsed GraphQL DocumentNode, so use `graphql-tag`.
If unset, the element can derive the document from the first
light-DOM `<script type="application/graphql">` child.

properties.name: context
properties.description: Context to be passed to link execution chain.

properties.name: data
properties.description: Latest mutation data.

properties.name: error
properties.description: Latest error

properties.name: errors
properties.description: Latest errors

properties.name: loading
properties.description: Whether a request is in flight.

events.name: will-mutate
events.description: When the element is about to mutate. Useful for setting variables. Prevent default to prevent mutation. Detail is `{ element: this }`

events.name: mutation-completed
events.description: When the mutation resolves. `detail` is `{ data: TData, element: this }`

events.name: mutation-navigation
events.description: When the mutation resolves and the element is about to navigate. cancel the event to handle navigation yourself e.g. using a client-side router. . `detail` is `{ data: TData, element: this }`

events.name: mutation-error
events.description:
When the mutation is rejected. `detail` is `{ error: ApolloError, element: this }`

### Example: Using data attributes
```html
<apollo-mutation data-type="Type" data-action="ACTION">
<mwc-button slot="trigger">OK</mwc-button>
</apollo-mutation>
```
Will mutate with the following as `variables`:
```json
{
"type": "Type",
"action": "ACTION"
}
```

### Example: Using data attributes and variables
```html
<apollo-mutation data-type="Quote" data-action="FLUB">
<mwc-button slot="trigger">OK</mwc-button>
<mwc-textfield slot="variable"
data-variable="name"
value="Neil"></mwc-textfield>
<textarea slot="variable"
data-variable="comment"
value="That's one small step..."></mwc-textfield>
</apollo-mutation>
```
Will mutate with the following as `variables`:
```json
{
"name": "Neil",
"comment": "That's one small step...",
"type": "Quote",
"action": "FLUB"
}
```

### Example: Using data attributes and variables with input property
```html
<apollo-mutation data-type="Type" data-action="ACTION" input-key="actionInput">
<mwc-button slot="trigger">OK</mwc-button>
<mwc-textfield slot="variable"
data-variable="comment"
value="Hey!"></mwc-textfield>
</apollo-mutation>
```
Will mutate with the following as `variables`:
```json
{
"actionInput": {
"comment": "Hey!",
"type": "Type",
"action": "ACTION"
}
}
```

### Example: Using DOM properties
```js
html`
<apollo-mutation
.mutation="${SomeMutation}"
.variables="${{ type: "Type", action: "ACTION" }}">
<mwc-button slot="trigger">OK</mwc-button>
</apollo-mutation>
```
Will mutate with the following as `variables`:
```json
{
"type": "Type",
"action": "ACTION"
}
```

slots.name: trigger
slots.description: the triggering element (e.g. button or anchor)

slots.name: variable
slots.description: an input-like element with a `data-variable` attribute. it's `value` property will be queried to get the value for the corresponding variable
